importance: This paper is crucial for researchers in HCI and machine learning because it introduces a novel approach for generating synthetic data for Chinese inertial writing recognition.  **It addresses the significant challenge of limited data availability in this domain**, opening new avenues for improving recognition accuracy and efficiency. This is especially relevant given the growing interest in inclusive technologies and the increasing use of inertial sensors in wearable devices. The release of the first Chinese writing recognition dataset based on inertial sensors further enhances the paper's impact on the research community.
summary: CI-GAN, a novel generative adversarial network, produces unlimited high-quality inertial writing signals for Chinese characters, significantly improving writing recognition accuracy from 6.7% to 98.4%.
takeaways: CI-GAN generates unlimited high-quality inertial writing signals for Chinese characters.
The proposed method significantly improves the accuracy of Chinese inertial writing recognition.
The first public Chinese writing recognition dataset based on inertial sensors is released.
tldr:
Current human-computer interaction (HCI) methods based on keyboards are insufficient for disabled individuals, particularly for those with visual impairments or limited hand mobility.  Inertial sensor-based systems offer a promising alternative due to their small size and cost-effectiveness, but accurate recognition requires large datasets which are difficult to obtain for the complexity of the Chinese language.  This creates a significant obstacle in developing efficient HCI systems for disabled people in this context.
This paper addresses these challenges by introducing CI-GAN, a novel Chinese inertial generative adversarial network. CI-GAN incorporates Chinese Glyph Encoding (CGE) for shape and stroke feature representation, Forced Optimal Transport (FOT) to improve signal authenticity, and Semantic Relevance Alignment (SRA) to enhance the semantic quality.  **CI-GAN generates unlimited, high-quality training samples**, which significantly enhance the accuracy of six tested writing classifiers (improved from 6.7% to 98.4%). Moreover, the paper releases a new dataset of Chinese writing samples obtained via inertial sensors.
